abstract.p: Robert E Kay letter on Sara Mosle's August 27 review of Diane Ravitch's book Left Back offers several observations on evaluating education reform (S)

block.p: In evaluating educational reform (see Sara Mosle on Diane Ravitch's ''Left Back,'' Aug. 27), a few basic observations should be kept in mind.

1. In 1840, when we and Scotland were the two most literate nations on earth, there were many ''one-room'' schools with 250 or more kids headed up by just one teacher and two assistants who helped the older stimulate, guide and control the younger.
2. Sweden, now No. 1 in literacy, worries about readiness and brain development. Therefore, they let no child inside a school building before the age of 7 -- and then graduate them in just 9 years.
3. In America, virtually all subject matter is (at all levels) anxiously memorized, then forgotten after the final exam is over. Teaching can't make integrated learning happen.

4. What we need in the real world, as opposed to the ''credential world,'' are these (partly inborn) basic skills: the ability to speak, listen, think, read, write, calculate, push a few buttons, cooperate, ask relevant questions, borrow ideas and get help from others (in school, this is often called cheating).

5. And finally, in addition to all we learn on the job, more than 1.5 million curious, confident, high-achieving and sociable home-schooled kids have demonstrated that the Prussian-derived, factory-oriented, teach 'em-test 'em, fear-provoking approaches of the mid-19th century may, in fact, be unnecessary or counterproductive.
